description:
This feature is superseded by appSecurity-2.0. Support for securing the server runtime environment and applications. This feature enables servlet-3.0 and web application security, support for LDAP and basic user registries, and SSL. To support secure EJB applications, you must add the ejbLite-3.1 feature. When you add this feature to your server, you need to configure a user registry, such as the basic user registry or the LDAP user registry.

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install appSecurity-1.0
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install appSecurity-1.0 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>appSecurity-1.0</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

  • For the complete feature documentation, see the appSecurity-1.0 feature description in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For more detailed installation instructions, including using Installation Manager and WebSphere Developer Tools, see Installing Liberty Repository assets in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For offline installation from a directory-based repository using 8.5.5.8 or higher, see Installing assets using the installUtility command in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For system requirements, see WebSphere Application Server detailed system requirements. Select the appropriate release, and click WebSphere Application Server (all editions). Select the edition, and choose the offering you want in Requirements by component.
name: Application Security 1.0
shortDescription: This feature is superseded by appSecurity-2.0. Support for securing the server runtime environment and applications. This feature enables servlet-3.0 and web application security, support for LDAP and basic user registries, and SSL. To support secure EJB applications, you must add the ejbLite-3.1 feature. When you add this feature to your server, you need to configure a user registry, such as the basic user registry or the LDAP user registry.

javaSEVersionRequirements.versionDisplayString: Java SE 7, Java SE 8, Java SE 11, Java SE 13

description:
This feature enables support for securing the server runtime environment and applications; it includes a basic user registry. This feature supersedes appSecurity-1.0 and does not include servlet-3.0 or support for the LDAP user registry. To secure web applications, add the servlet-3.0 feature. To secure EJB applications, add the ejbLite-3.1 feature. To use LDAP, add the ldapRegistry-3.0 feature. When you add the appSecurity-2.0 feature to your server, you need to configure a user registry, such as the basic user registry or the LDAP user registry.

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install appSecurity-2.0
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install appSecurity-2.0 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>appSecurity-2.0</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

  • For the complete feature documentation, see the appSecurity-2.0 feature description in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For more detailed installation instructions, including using Installation Manager and WebSphere Developer Tools, see Installing Liberty Repository assets in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For offline installation from a directory-based repository using 8.5.5.8 or higher, see Installing assets using the installUtility command in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For system requirements, see WebSphere Application Server detailed system requirements. Select the appropriate release, and click WebSphere Application Server (all editions). Select the edition, and choose the offering you want in Requirements by component.

description:
This feature enables connections to Cloudant by providing a connector instance configured in the server configuration, which can be injected or accessed through JNDI. Applications use the Cloudant client library to utilize the connector instance.

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install cloudant-1.0
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install cloudant-1.0 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>cloudant-1.0</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

  • For the complete feature documentation, see the cloudant-1.0 feature description in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For more detailed installation instructions, including using Installation Manager and WebSphere Developer Tools, see Installing Liberty Repository assets in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For offline installation from a directory-based repository using 8.5.5.8 or higher, see Installing assets using the installUtility command in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For system requirements, see WebSphere Application Server detailed system requirements. Select the appropriate release, and click WebSphere Application Server (all editions). Select the edition, and choose the offering you want in Requirements by component.

description:
This feature enables the creation of managed executors that allow applications to submit tasks to run concurrently, with thread context that is managed by the application server.It also enables the creation of managed thread factories to create threads that run with the threadcontext of the component that looks up the managed thread factory.

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install concurrent-1.0
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install concurrent-1.0 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>concurrent-1.0</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

  • For the complete feature documentation, see the concurrent-1.0 feature description in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For more detailed installation instructions, including using Installation Manager and WebSphere Developer Tools, see Installing Liberty Repository assets in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For offline installation from a directory-based repository using 8.5.5.8 or higher, see Installing assets using the installUtility command in IBM Knowledge Center.

description:
This feature enables support for the Java Architecture for XML Binding 2.2 specification, which provides easy mapping of Java classes to XML documents.

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install jaxb-2.2
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install jaxb-2.2 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>jaxb-2.2</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

  • For the complete feature documentation, see the jaxb-2.2 feature description in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For more detailed installation instructions, including using Installation Manager and WebSphere Developer Tools, see Installing Liberty Repository assets in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For offline installation from a directory-based repository using 8.5.5.8 or higher, see Installing assets using the installUtility command in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For system requirements, see WebSphere Application Server detailed system requirements. Select the appropriate release, and click WebSphere Application Server (all editions). Select the edition, and choose the offering you want in Requirements by component.
name: Java XML Bindings 2.2
shortDescription: This feature enables support for the Java Architecture for XML Binding 2.2 specification, which provides easy mapping of Java classes to XML documents.

description:
This feature enables support for Java API for RESTful Web Services. JAX-RS annotations can be used to define web service clients and endpoints that comply with the REST architectural style. Endpoints are accessed through a common interface that is based on the HTTP standard methods.

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install jaxrs-2.0
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install jaxrs-2.0 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>jaxrs-2.0</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

  • For the complete feature documentation, see the jaxrs-2.0 feature description in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For more detailed installation instructions, including using Installation Manager and WebSphere Developer Tools, see Installing Liberty Repository assets in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For offline installation from a directory-based repository using 8.5.5.8 or higher, see Installing assets using the installUtility command in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For system requirements, see WebSphere Application Server detailed system requirements. Select the appropriate release, and click WebSphere Application Server (all editions). Select the edition, and choose the offering you want in Requirements by component.
name: Java RESTful Services 2.0
shortDescription: This feature enables support for Java API for RESTful Web Services.  JAX-RS annotations can be used to define web service clients and endpoints that comply with the REST architectural style. Endpoints are accessed through a common interface that is based on the HTTP standard methods.

description:
This feature enables the configuration of resource adapters to access Enterprise Information Systems (EIS) from applications. The configuration of a resource adapter also includes the configuration of connection factories, administered objects and activation specifications. Any resource adapter that complies with the JCA 1.7 specification or lower can be used. High performance connection pooling is also provided.

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install jca-1.7
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install jca-1.7 --when-file-exists=ignore

<featureManager>
  <feature>jca-1.7</feature>

description:
This feature enables support for applications that use application-managed and container-managed JPA. This feature includes Java Persistence API 2.1 specification interfaces and container-managed JPA integration. EclipseLink is also included as the default JPA provider implementation.

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install jpa-2.1
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install jpa-2.1 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>jpa-2.1</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

description:
This feature enables CDI integrations for web applications that use the Java Server Faces (JSF) 2.2 framework. This feature only includes container integration code for JSF, and does not include any JSF interfaces or implementation. To use this feature, JSF interfaces and implementation must be packaged within web applications that use JSF.

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install jsfContainer-2.2
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install jsfContainer-2.2 --when-file-exists=ignore

<featureManager>

When this feature is enabled, there is no built-in JSON-P provider. Instead, configure a JSON-P provider via a which points at a library containing the JSON-P provider JAR file(s).

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install jsonpContainer-1.1
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install jsonpContainer-1.1 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>jsonpContainer-1.1</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

  • For the complete feature documentation, see the jsonpContainer-1.1 feature description in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For more detailed installation instructions, including using Installation Manager and WebSphere Developer Tools, see Installing Liberty Repository assets in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For offline installation from a directory-based repository using 8.5.5.8 or higher, see Installing assets using the installUtility command in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For system requirements, see WebSphere Application Server detailed system requirements. Select the appropriate release, and click WebSphere Application Server (all editions). Select the edition, and choose the offering you want in Requirements by component.
name: JavaScript Object Notation Processing 1.1 via Bells
shortDescription: The Java API for JSON Processing (JSON-P) feature provides a standardized method for constructing and manipulating data to be rendered in JavaScript Object Notation (JSON). When this feature is enabled, there is no built-in JSON-P provider. Instead, configure a JSON-P provider via a <bell> which points at a library containing the JSON-P provider JAR file(s).

description:
This feature allows the use of a local JMX connector that is built into the JVM to access JMX resources in the server. The JMX connector can only be used on the same host machine by a client that has the same user ID and the same JDK as the server process. It enables local access by JMX clients such as jConsole, or other JMX clients that use the Attach API.

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install localConnector-1.0
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install localConnector-1.0 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>localConnector-1.0</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

description:
A secure, REST administrative connector that can be used locally or remotely using any Java developer kit. This connector enables remote access from a Java client or directly through an HTTPS call. The administrator and reader roles protect the connector. The connector requires TLS to keep the communication confidential. The HTTPS port used by the connector is defined through the default HTTP endpoint. This feature supersedes the restConnector-1.0 feature. It enables the REST handler configuration APIs. When this feature is combined with features supporting configuration validation, the corresponding REST handler validation APIs are enabled.

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install restConnector-2.0
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install restConnector-2.0 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>restConnector-2.0</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

  • For the complete feature documentation, see the restConnector-2.0 feature description in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For more detailed installation instructions, including using Installation Manager and WebSphere Developer Tools, see Installing Liberty Repository assets in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For offline installation from a directory-based repository using 8.5.5.8 or higher, see Installing assets using the installUtility command in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For system requirements, see WebSphere Application Server detailed system requirements. Select the appropriate release, and click WebSphere Application Server (all editions). Select the edition, and choose the offering you want in Requirements by component.

bin/installUtility install springBoot-1.5
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install springBoot-1.5 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>springBoot-1.5</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

  • For the complete feature documentation, see the springBoot-1.5 feature description in IBM Knowledge Center.

description:
The wasJmsClient-2.0 feature provides applications with access to the message queues that are hosted on WebSphere Application Server through the JMS 2.0 API. This feature supersedes wasJmsClient-1.1. The wasJmsClient-2.0 feature is compliant with JMS 2.0 specifications and is supported only on JDK 7 or later. It enables access to the messaging engine that is enabled through the wasJmsServer feature, and also to the service integration bus that is hosted on a full profile server.

Command Line Install

To install the feature from the command line, type:
bin/installUtility install wasJmsClient-2.0
If you are installing into 8.5.5.5 or earlier and the feature supports that version, use the featureManager command, for example:
bin/featureManager install wasJmsClient-2.0 --when-file-exists=ignore

Config Instructions

To use the feature at runtime add the following to your server.xml file
<featureManager>
  <feature>wasJmsClient-2.0</feature>
</featureManager>

Additional Information

  • For the complete feature documentation, see the wasJmsClient-2.0 feature description in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For more detailed installation instructions, including using Installation Manager and WebSphere Developer Tools, see Installing Liberty Repository assets in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For offline installation from a directory-based repository using 8.5.5.8 or higher, see Installing assets using the installUtility command in IBM Knowledge Center.
  • For system requirements, see WebSphere Application Server detailed system requirements. Select the appropriate release, and click WebSphere Application Server (all editions). Select the edition, and choose the offering you want in Requirements by component.
